passages.text: King of Causeway Bay: cross the curve, top pick is \(7.2\%\) per

Hysan Development Company (Hysan) is the largest landlord in Causeway Bay, a prime shopping area in Hong Kong. With its high- quality shopping malls that account for half of its revenue, we think the company is well- positioned to benefit from an expected recovery in the Hong Kong retail property sector. Indeed, its earnings are already showing signs of recovery, and this should continue. Such recovery and the recently announced capital recycling plan should help its credit metrics to improve gradually, before accelerating into 2027 with maiden contributions from Lee Gardens Eight. We move to OW on Hysan and are OW along the curve ( \(27\%\) , \(29\%\) & \(35\%\) ) and its perpetual bonds ( \(7.2\%\) \(c30s\) and \(4.85\%\) fixed- for- life). Our top pick is the \(7.2\%\) perpetual bond, a Baa3 rated bond offering \(\sim 7\%\) yield.

- Earnings Cycle Has Bottomed Out: Hysan has felt the downward pressure of the Hong Kong property downcycle. Its EBITDA fell by approximately \(30\%\) over the 2019-23 period, but its recent results (2024 and 1H25) underscored that the worst is over. We expect the recovery to continue to be driven by higher retail occupancy (completion of the rejuvenation program could add back \(4\%\) of floor space) and higher rental rates. While its Hong Kong office rents will still feel some downward pressure, the segment's earnings could be partially cushioned by the ramp-up of Lee Gardens Shanghai.

- Lee Gardens Eight (LGE) to Add Another Layer of Cash Flow: This \(60\%\) - owned project, due for completion in 2H26, will increase Hysan's attributable gross floor area by \(15\%\) . The company has invested HK\(26 billion (100\%\) of the project) thus far and may need another HK\(2-3 billion to complete the project. Notwithstanding the challenging market conditions for office rentals, the project should become a cash generator by 2027, after being a burden on the balance sheet for the past few years.

- Balance Sheet Remains Healthy for Its Rating: While the company's leverage looks elevated at 9.6x in 2024, its adjusted net debt to investment properties is healthy at approximately \(30\%\) . Importantly, its investment properties are conservatively valued, e.g., 5.25-5.0% for retail, 4.25-5.0% for office, and 3.75% for residential. Its debt service coverage ratio also looks adequate at approximately 2.0x and should improve with a lower HIBOR. With HK\(3.3 billion in cash and HK\)12 billion of undrawn committed bank lines, the company also has sufficient liquidity to cover its near-term maturities. The recently announced HK\(8 billion capital recycling plan over five years could provide another liquidity buffer.

- Moving to OW on Attractive Valuations for an Improving Credit: We are moving our issuer rating on Hysan and ratings on its '29s and '35s to OW from N, while maintaining OW on '27s. We also initiate coverage of Hysan 7.2% perpetual 'c30s (7.0%ytc) with an OW and upgrade 4.85% fixed-for-life perpetual (6.93%ytw) to OW from UW. Key risks are 1) lower rental and vacancy rates for its office properties; 2) potential new supply given its upcoming HKD and CNY bond maturities.

J.P. Morgan does and seeks to do business with companies covered in its research reports. As a result, investors should be aware that the firm may have a conflict of interest that could affect the objectivity of this report. Investors should consider this report as only a single factor in making their investment decision.

We are moving our issuer rating on Hysan to OW from N as we believe that Hysan is an improving credit story. Recent results have underscored that the worst is over for the company. Improved contributions from its Hong Kong retail malls and Lee Gardens Shanghai should more than compensate for lower rental income from its office buildings. We expect credit metrics to improve over this year and next. Into 2027, maiden contributions from Lee Gardens Eight will add another layer of cash flow, accelerating the credit improvement trend.

We believe that the closer comps for Hysan would be other Hong Kong property names. Hysan bonds are trading slightly inside of Nan Fung. We believe that such a slight premium for Hysan is well warranted given Nan Fung Group has more exposure to the inherently more volatile residential property market and is unlisted (thus less transparency). Other Hong Kong property companies (e.g., Hong Kong Land, LInk REIT, Sun Hung Kai) are single- A rated and thus trading well inside of the Hysan curve. Relative to these single- A names, we believe that Hysan bonds offer relative value. Their spread pick- up (in STW terms) is currently hovering at the wider end of its historical trading range since mid- 2023. We are moving our recommendations on Hysan '29s and '35s to OW from N, and are keeping our OW on '27s.
Figure 1: Hysan '29s trades 72bp wider than HK Land '30s STW in bp
Figure 2: Hysan '35s trades 77bp wider than HK Land '33s STW in bp
Source: J.P. Morgan.

We also initiate coverage of Hysan \(7.2\%\) perpetual 'c30s with an OW. The bonds are offering higher yields than some HY names. We expect the bonds to be redeemed in 2030, even though we recognize that the perp coupon could be reset at a lower rate of \(6.97\%\) (based on current H155Y) and potentially even lower if interest rates move lower. However, the company's recent redemption of US \(850 million 4.1\%\) perp, whose coupon would have reset to \(6.16\%\) (based on current rates), which is lower than \(7.2\%\) coupon on this perp, underscored the company's commitment to meet bondholders' expectations.

The recent redemption of the 4.1% perp has led to some concern that Moody's may lower its rating on the 7.2% perp to Ba1, given that the current Baa3 rating is conditional on the presence of more junior securities, failing which the rating agency may notch down its rating on the perp by two notches below the issuer's rating instead of one as currently. During our recent call with the company, management reiterated their earlier guidance to the market that the company will issue another tranche of junior securities to satisfy Moody's condition. We are comfortable that Hysan should be able to satisfy this condition, which is rather lax as it only requires a small tranche of junior securities.

We are also moving our recommendation on 4.85% fixed-for-life perp to OW from UW.The bonds are offering a similar yield to the 7.2% perp. The former has a longer tenure but is structurally more senior and thus rated one notch higher at Baa2. We recognize that the 4.85% perp is a leverage play on interest rates given its duration, and its low dollar price offers some downside protection. However, if we had to make a choice, we would have a preference for the shorter-dated 7.2% perp.

Hysan has felt the downward pressure of the Hong Kong property downcycle. Its EBITDA fell by approximately \(30\%\) over the 2019- 23 period as occupancy rates and monthly rental rates fell. However, its recent results (2024 and 1H25) underscored that the worst is over. While its office rentals are still under pressure, the other two segments have shown signs of recovery. In particular, its retail shopping malls have seen its occupancy rising to \(94\% (+2\%\) points) and rental rates have improved to an estimated \(\mathrm{HKS175psf(+7\%}\) higher than 2024 rental) in 1H25. We expect the recovery to continue to be driven by higher retail occupancy and higher rental rates. Over the past two years, Hysan has closed \(3 - 4\%\) of its retail space as part of a rejuvenation program. These areas should start to contribute again once the enhancement works are completed.

While its Hong Kong office rents will still feel some downward pressure, the segment's earnings could be partially cushioned by the ramp- up of Lee Gardens Shanghai acquired in 2022. The office building with 0.9 million sq ft of gross floor area contributed \(\mathrm{HKS67}\) million in office rentals in 2024 and \(\mathrm{HKS47}\) million in 1H25, helping to buffer the downward pressure on Hong Kong office rentals. We expect its contribution to continue to rise as its occupancy rate has improved to \(68\%\) in 1H25 from \(41\%\) in 2024.
Figure 4: Hysan - Occupancy rate In %
Source: Company reports and J.P. Morgan estimates.
Figure 5: Hysan - Monthly rental rates
Source: Company reports and J.P. Morgan estimates.

This \(60\%\) - owned project is due for completion in the second half of 2026. With approximately 1 million square feet of gross area ( \(90\%\) office and \(10\%\) retail), Lee Gardens Eight (LGE) will increase Hysan's attributable gross floor area by \(15\%\) . Hysan and its partner, Chinachem Group, have thus far invested \(\mathrm{HKS26}\) billion ( \(100\%\) of the project) in the project and may need another \(\mathrm{HKS2 - 3}\) billion to complete it. Notwithstanding the challenging market conditions for office rentals, the project should become a cash generator by 2027, in our view. Assuming a monthly rental of \(\mathrm{HKS52}\) per square foot and an occupancy rate of \(90\%\) , the building could potentially add \(\mathrm{HK}\) \(261\) million of rental income ( \(7 - 8\%\) of additional revenue) on a full run- rate basis. However, this could take time to materialize given the current market conditions.

While we recognize that the company's leverage looks elevated at 9.6x in 2024, its adjusted net debt to investment properties is healthy at approximately \(30\%\) . Note that both Moody's and Fitch rate Hysan using its REIT rating methodology, and thus their focus is on gearing. Another point to note is that Hysan has valued its investment properties relatively conservatively at \(5.25 - 5.0\%\) for retail, \(4.25 - 5.0\%\) for office, and \(3.75\%\) for residential.

Its debt service coverage ratio also looks adequate at approximately 2.0x and should improve with a lower HIBOR. With an estimated HK\\$15 billion in bank loans that account for around half of its total debt (excluding the perpetual bonds), Hysan could see HK\\$150 million in savings in interest expense for a 1 percentage point change in HIBOR.

The company's liquidity position also looks healthy with HK\\$3.3 billion in cash and HK \(12 billion of undrawn committed bank lines (as of June 2025). After the recent redemption of US\) 850 million \(4.1\%\) perpetual bonds (US\\$750 million outstanding), the pro forma liquidity reserve would still add up to HK\\$9.45 billion, which is more than sufficient to cover its debt maturities in 2025 and 2026 totaling HK\\$2.7 billion. Hysan's next lumpy maturity will be its secured bank loans raised to fund Lee Gardens Eight. We are comfortable that Hysan and its partner will be able to refinance the loan, particularly as the project will be completed by then.
Table 2: Hysan - Key financials and ratios
Source: Company reports and J.P. Morgan estimates.

The recently announced HKS8 billion capital recycling plan over the next five years could provide an additional liquidity buffer. Hysan has identified several non- core assets for divestment. These include: 1) two blocks within the Bamboo Grove; 2) built- to- sell units from Villa Lucca; and 3) the To Kwa Wan residential development. Given the improved market sentiment for the Hong Kong residential property market, we expect these divestments could enhance Hysan's cash flow this year and next.

Hysan Development Company Limited (Hysan) was originally founded by Lee Hysan's family as Lee Hysan Estate Co. in 1923. Hysan was then officially incorporated in 1970 and is now a Hong Kong- based real estate firm engaged in the development, investment, and management of commercial and residential properties. Over the past century, Hysan has acquired various plots of land and properties in Causeway Bay. The company was listed on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange (HKEX) under the stock code 14. HK in September 1981. As of Aug 26, 2025, the company had a total market capitalization of HK\$15.6 billion (US\$2 billion).

Outside Hong Kong, Hysan has two properties in Shanghai: (1) Lee Gardens Shanghai, a fully- owned office and retail complex with 931 sq.ft of gross floor area, was acquired in 2022, with its retail podium renovated in 2024; (2) Grand Gateway 66, an office, retail, and residential complex developed in joint venture with Hang Lung Properties, where Hysan holds a 26% stake. This project includes a mix of a 50- story office tower, retail mall, and 700 furnished apartments, covering over 2.9 million sq.ft in gross floor area. Its 1H25 revenue breakdown was: 1) 49% from retail rental; 2) 41% from office rental; 3) 7% from residential rental; 4) 3% from Lee Gardens Shanghai.

Currently, Hysan has three projects under development or in the sales process: (1) Lee Garden Eight, an office and retail complex jointly developed with Chinachem Group, where Hysan holds a 60% stake. With over 1 million sq.ft of gross floor area, Lee Garden Eight is expected to be the largest commercial floor plate on Hong Kong Island upon its targeted completion in 2026; (2) VILLA LUCCA, a low- density luxury residential project in the Tai Po district, jointly developed with HKR International Limited. Completed in 2023, this project offers 262 residences, including garden houses and apartments, with 53% contracted as of Jun 2025; (3) To Kwa Wan Residential Project, an Urban Renewal Authority residential project at Bailey Street/Wing Kwong Street in Kowloon's To Kwa Wan district, being developed by the joint venture of Hysan, Henderson Land, and Empire Group, in which Hysan holds a 25% stake. It is

targeted for completion in early 2027, offering over 700k sq.ft of gross floor area upon completion. To deleverage, Hysan recently initiated an HK\\$8 billion capital recycling program over the next five years to divest part of its non-core residential assets, including Bamboo Grove (2 blocks), VILLA LUCCA, and the To Kwa Wan Residential Project.

The HK retail market has sharply corrected since 2019, with prime retail rents plunging \(40\%\) alongside a surge in vacancy from below \(3\%\) to \(- 10\%\) . This is attributable to a prolonged Covid lockdown, as well as a weak market recovery post reopening. The slow recovery was a result of (1) northbound consumption leakage, (2) reduced inbound tourists as a result of HKD appreciation, and (3) behavioural change of Mainland China tourists (from buying luxury goods to city exploration).

We note that HK retail sales have started to recover with a small positive YoY growth in 2Q25, led by solid staples sales, and improved tourist traffic thanks to a weaker HKD this year. JLL expects retail rents and capital values to drop another \(5 - 10\%\) in 2025, but it believes the downside is limited after the sharp correction since 2019. Retail rents will likely stabilize into 2026 as the retail market gradually bottoms out.
Figure 6: Hong Kong overall prime retail - Vacancy rate in %
Source: JLL, J.P. Morgan Equity Research.
Figure 7: Hong Kong overall prime retail - Monthly rental rates In HK\$/psf
Source: JLL, J.P. Morgan Equity Research.

The HK office market has seen deteriorating oversupply since 2018, as a result of (1) demand contraction due to subdued capital market activities & increased corporate relocation away from HK, and (2) a heavy supply pipeline. Office rents/capital values have dropped \(\sim 40\% /50\%\) from peak, and vacancy rate more than tripled from \(4.2\%\) to \(13.6\%\) over 2018- mid 2025.

In a recent interview, JLL noted that the improved IPO momentum in HK in 1H25 is insufficient to drive a turnaround in the office sector. It forecasts office vacancies to rise further to \(15.1\% /15.9\%\) by the end of 2025/27 due to heavy new supply (eg. IGC by SHKP in West Kowloon, One Causeway Bay by Mandarin Oriental), before moderating to \(15.2\%\) by 2029. Rents will likely decline further by \(\sim 3\%\) p.a. in 2025/26 amidst high vacancy and upcoming supply, before reaching a floor in 2027.
Figure 8: Hong Kong office vacancy rates in %
Source: JLL, J.P. Morgan Equity Research.
Figure 9: Hong Kong office - Rental value index 1997=100
Source: JLL, J.P. Morgan Equity Research.

For all Korea-based Research Analysts listed on the front cover, if applicable, they also certify, as per KOFIA requirements, that the Research Analyst's analysis was made in good faith and that the views reflect the Research Analyst's own opinion, without undue influence or intervention.

J.P. Morgan uses a bond- level rating system that incorporates valuations (relative value) and our fundamental view on the security. Our fundamental credit view of an issuer is based on the company's underlying credit trends, overall creditworthiness and our opinion on whether the issuer will be able to service its debt obligations when they become due and payable. We analyze, among other things, the company's cash flow capacity and trends and standard credit ratios, such as gross and net leverage, interest coverage and liquidity ratios. We also analyze profitability, capitalization and asset quality, among other variables, when assessing financials. Analysts also rate the issuer, based on the rating of the benchmark or representative security. Unless we specify a different recommendation for the company's individual securities, an issuer recommendation applies to all of the bonds at the same level of the issuer's capital structure. We may also rate certain loans and preferred securities, as applicable. This report also sets out within it the material underlying assumptions used. We use the following ratings for bonds (issues), issuers, loans, and preferred securities: Overweight (over the next three months, the recommended risk position is expected to outperform the relevant index, sector, or benchmark); Neutral (over the next three months, the recommended risk position is expected to perform in line with the relevant index, sector, or benchmark); and Underweight (over the next three months, the recommended risk position is expected to underperform the relevant index, sector, or benchmark). J.P. Morgan Emerging Markets Sovereign Research uses Marketweight, which is equivalent to Neutral. NR is Not Rated. In this case, J.P. Morgan has removed the rating for this particular security or issuer because of either a lack of a sufficient fundamental basis or for legal, regulatory or policy reasons. The previous rating no longer should be relied upon. An NR designation is not a recommendation or a rating. NC is Not Covered. An NC designation is not a rating or a recommendation. For CDS, we use the following rating system: Long Risk (over the next three months, the credit return on the recommended position is expected to exceed the relevant index, sector or benchmark); Neutral (over the next three months, the credit return on the recommended position is expected to match the relevant index, sector or benchmark); and Short Risk (over the next three months, the credit return on the recommended position is expected to underperform the relevant index, sector or benchmark).
